etymologies: late Middle English (in the sense ‘not in full grammatical concord’): from medieval Latin indirectus, from in- ‘not’ + directus (see direct)

definitions: not directly caused by or resulting from something

examples.text: full employment would have an indirect effect on wage levels

shortDefinitions: not directly caused by or resulting from something

definitions: not done directly; conducted through intermediaries

examples.text: the nature of the threat can be pieced together only from indirect evidence

definitions: (of costs) deriving from overhead charges or subsidiary work

examples.text: hidden or indirect costs involved in training

shortDefinitions: (of costs) deriving from overheads or subsidiary work

definitions: (of taxation) levied on goods and services rather than income or profits.
shortDefinitions: (of taxation) levied on goods and services rather than income

definitions: (of a route) not straight; not following the shortest way

examples.text: he took a careful, indirect route home from his dockside rendezvous

definitions: (of lighting) from a concealed source and diffusely reflected

examples.text: fittings were installed to give a subdued, indirect light in the nave

definitions: denoting a free kick from which a goal may not be scored directly.
shortDefinitions: denoting free kick from which goal may not be scored directly

definitions: avoiding direct mention or exposition of a subject

examples.text: an indirect attack on the Senator
